Comment: This game is a trial by fire of the alternative move (5...f6). I had to find out if this move can refute the gambit. I present the following game with my strategic ideas for your enjoyment.

Here is seen the (5...f6) alternative move. The computer typically likes to play ...Nc6, but I make it play the text move so I can have some fun with this variation of the Boden-Kierseritsky Gambit.
Activates the rook. White has 5 active pieces vs black who has almost 2 active pieces.
!? An interesting move with the idea of ...d5 to follow. This creates a strong center, or is it? Pawns chains are only as strong as their weakest link. Note the expansive pawn structure that follows.

!? Sure, you are thinking what kind of a dumb move is that? It does nothing to challenge ...d5? I made this move based on intuition and because it can be used to break the pawn chain later by b4-b5, and it prevents ...Bc5, denying the bishop a centralized position.
Expected.
The text move maintains the bishop on its best attacking line and allows for a later c4, which if follows ...0-0, becomes a very useful move.
...0-0 is expected.

!? Opens a queen line, pushes the knight towards an expected castle, and can possibly entice a bad move like ...g5 creating an ever increasing amount of luft around the king. Threatens Qh5+ where if ...g6 then Nxg6 wins a pawn.
Blissfully unaware.
! Breaking the chain. Its not obvious how good this move really is until it is taken in context of the following moves.
?! Not forced, seems better to leave the tension.
! Breaking the chain on the other flank, the central pawns are demolished. The threat of check is hanging.
Gains material but misses the threat.
A simpleton check.
A simpleton check.
?! Trying to avoid the bishop check, but stepping into tactics.
?! Trying to avoid the bishop check, but stepping into tactics.
! A kicker of a move breaks down the castle walls.
Losing the rook may have been preferable.
Not just gain material, but threatening Rh4+
